summary: This is a Federal Bureau of Prisons investigative report concerning an incident on July 23, 2019, where inmate Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell with a homemade noose around his neck. The report details the incident, subsequent medical assessments, and interviews with Epstein and his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, concluding there was insufficient evidence of assault and no need for a separation order. This document is a Bureau of Prisons Form 583 Report of Incident and accompanying staff memoranda detailing the events of July 23, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York, where inmate Jeffrey Epstein was found with an orange cloth around his neck. The reports describe the response, Epstein's subsequent allegations against his cellmate, and the conflicting accounts of whether it was a suicide attempt or an assault. This document contains Bureau of Prisons records from July 23, 2019, detailing the incident where Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell with a rope around his neck. It includes staff shift logs, a clinical encounter report, photo sheets documenting the scene and his cellmate, an administrative detention order, and an incident report. The records show Epstein was placed on suicide watch and treated for neck injuries.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The primary subject of the report. Found in his cell with a homemade noose, placed on suicide watch, and interviewed about the incident. He denies being suicidal and claims no issues with his cellmate.

persons.name: Nicholas Tartaglione
persons.context: Epstein's cellmate at the time of the incident. Interviewed by staff, stated he found Epstein on the floor and called for help. Reported that Epstein made him uncomfortable by stating 'fourteen (14) is legal in most states'.

persons.name: Thomas, Michael
persons.context: A staff member listed on the incident form and daily roster; authored a memorandum stating he assisted in carrying Epstein to the HA-Unit.

persons.name: Noel, T
persons.context: Listed on the daily assignment roster as having 'Day Off' on July 23, 2019.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: The primary subject of the documents; found in his cell with a rope around his neck in an apparent suicide attempt. He was treated for injuries and placed on suicide watch.

persons.name: Thomas, M
persons.context: A staff member listed on shift logs, specifically noted for a time change related to suicide watch duties on the morning of July 23, 2019.

connections.description: Were housed together in the Special Housing Unit at MCC New York. Both were interviewed separately about the incident where Epstein was found with a noose.
Thomas, as a staff member, assisted in responding to the incident and transporting Epstein on a stretcher.
Were housed together in cell 124 of the Special Housing Unit at MCC New York. Tartaglione alerted staff to Epstein's condition.

events.title: Epstein Found with Homemade Noose
events.description: At approximately 1:27 a.m., staff found inmate Jeffrey Epstein lying on his cell floor in a fetal position with a homemade noose around his neck. He was breathing heavily, placed in restraints, and taken for medical examination, which found marks on his neck and knee. He was placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Interview of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Epstein was interviewed by SIS staff. He stated he had not slept in 20 days, was extremely tired, and only recalled being on the floor and snoring. He denied issues with Tartaglione, recalled Tartaglione calling him a 'pedophile' days earlier, and stated he did not feel suicidal.

events.title: Interview of Nicholas Tartaglione
events.description: Tartaglione was interviewed. He stated he was asleep on the floor when something hit his foot; he found Epstein sitting with eyes open, called his name, and banged on the door for help. He reported Epstein made him uncomfortable by stating 'fourteen (14) is legal in most states' and complained about his attorneys.

events.title: Epstein Placed in Administrative Detention
events.description: An Administrative Detention Order was issued placing Jeffrey Epstein in detention pending classification.

events.title: Epstein Found with Noose in Cell
events.description: At approximately 1:27 AM, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with an orange homemade cloth around his neck, appearing unresponsive. Staff responded, removed the cloth, and transported him for medical observation.

events.title: Epstein Alleges Cellmate Attempted Murder and Extortion
events.description: After becoming responsive, Epstein told staff he believed his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, tried to kill him and had been attempting to extort money from him for a week, threatening to beat him up.

events.title: Tartaglione's Account of Discovery
events.description: Tartaglione stated he was asleep, felt something hit his legs, turned on the light, and saw Epstein with a string around his neck, prompting him to call the guards.

events.title: Epstein Found Unresponsive in Cell
events.description: At approximately 1:27 AM, correctional staff found Jeffrey Epstein unresponsive in his cell with an orange homemade rope around his neck. His cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, alerted staff. Epstein was breathing but unresponsive. Staff removed the rope and he was taken out of the SHU.

events.title: Medical Assessment and Suicide Watch Placement
events.description: Epstein was assessed at Health Services at 6:20 AM. He had a circular line of erythema (redness) around his neck but was ambulatory, oriented, and smiling. He claimed not to know how the injury happened. He was placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Administrative Detention Order
events.description: Epstein was placed in Administrative Detention at his own request for his own protection, pending classification.

Receiving and Discharge Area at MCC New York

Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York, New York
Main Facility, Special Housing Unit (SHU), 9 SOUTH, Cell Z05-124LAD

Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, N.Y.
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell at approximately 1:27 a.m. on July 23, 2019, with a homemade noose around his neck, leading to a suicide watch placement.
Epstein told investigators he had not slept in about 20 days, was extremely tired, and had no memory of the noose incident, only recalling waking on the floor.

Cellmate Nicholas Tartaglione reported that Epstein had made him uncomfortable in a prior conversation by stating 'fourteen (14) is legal in most states and I don't understand what's the problem here'.
The Bureau of Prisons investigation concluded there was insufficient evidence that Epstein was assaulted by Tartaglione and no need for a separation order between the inmates.
Medical assessment of Epstein found a circular line of erythema and friction marks on his neck, and a small erythema on his left knee.
Jeffrey Epstein was found in his prison cell with an orange homemade cloth around his neck on July 23, 2019, at approximately 1:27 AM.
Epstein later alleged that his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, had tried to kill him and had been extorting him, claiming Tartaglione said staff would not report a beating due to Epstein's charges.
Staff reports note observing Epstein flicker his eyes and appear to pretend to be unconscious when staff made eye contact with him.
The incident was officially logged as a suicide attempt (method: hanging/asphyxiation) on a Bureau of Prisons Form 583.
Conflicting narratives are present: the official report frames it as a suicide attempt, while Epstein's subsequent statements allege an assault by his cellmate.
Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell at approximately 1:27 AM on July 23, 2019, with a homemade rope around his neck, in an incident documented as a 'Possible Suicide Attempt'.
Epstein's cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, was present and alerted staff to the situation.
A medical examination hours later revealed a circular line of erythema (redness) around Epstein's neck, but he was alert, oriented, smiling, and claimed not to know how the injury occurred.
Epstein had been placed in Administrative Detention on July 10, 2019, at his own request for protection.
The incident was formally reported as 'Self-Mutilation' under Prohibited Act Code 228 in a Bureau of Prisons Incident Report.
